qas.question: What is the most frequently used writing script for the Somali language?
In what month and year was the Somali alphabet introduced?

context: A number of writing systems have been used over the years for transcribing the language. Of these, <a0_0>the Somali alphabet<a0_0/> is the most widely used, and has been the official writing script in Somalia since the government of former President of Somalia <a1_0>Mohamed Siad Barre<a1_0/> formally introduced it in <a2_0>October 1972<a2_0/>. The script was developed by the Somali linguist <a3_0>Shire Jama Ahmed<a3_0/> specifically for the Somali language, and uses all letters of the English Latin alphabet except p, v and z. Besides Ahmed's Latin script, other orthographies that have been used for centuries for writing Somali include the long-established Arabic script and Wadaad's writing. Indigenous writing systems developed in the twentieth century include the Osmanya, Borama and Kaddare scripts, which were invented by <a4_0>Osman Yusuf Kenadid<a4_0/>, Abdurahman Sheikh Nuur and Hussein Sheikh Ahmed Kaddare, respectively.
